passages.text: JPM Friday Movie Quote/Song Lyric Quiz - Last time's Movie Quote was "I've done a lot of bad things, Joey. Maybe it's comin' back to me. Who knows? I'm a jinx maybe. Who the hell knows?" and was from Raging Bull, which only one person got. Clearly I need to make these easier. Back to Song Lyrics this week, and your lyric is "I wouldn't, if I were you / I know what she can do / She's deadly, man, she could really rip your world apart". As usual there's a glittering free day off for the first client or corporate to email me the name of the Song and Artist and mere Everlasting Glory for the first JPM Employee to send me the right answer. Good Luck

- TODAY - JPM Back to School Series Day 1 - SPM, ENI, EQNR- MONDAY - Nothing- CRUDE/EU GAS - front-end Brent closed +0.8% yday and is trading -0.4% this morning at \(68.3 / bbl, +0.8\%\) from the European close last night and +1.1% from this time yday morning. EU TTF Month Ahead gas closed -4% at €31/MWh- Oil Markets Weekly: Tariffs on India kick in—Russian oil flows likely to continue at limited discounts (research available). Despite higher tariffs, India continues to buy Russian crude at reduced levels, a trend likely to persist until a trade deal is finalized and Russia maintains discounts. Russia has successfully redirected the 0.5 mbd drop in Indian exports but is unlikely to offer discounts beyond the current \(2.60 / bbl\), preferring to cut production over providing the deep discounts seen in 2022. With only 0.2 mbd of this being shipped to the EU, India should face no issues in complying with EU third-country intermediaries restrictions. India operates within global policy frameworks, with Russia bearing the responsibility for delivery- US Gas Weekly & Storage Recap: Early-view week ending August 29, 2025: +51 Bcf (research available). Yday's EIA print once more came in below market expectations, which called for a build in the high 20s Bcf but was relatively in line with our supply-demand forecast calling for a 21 Bcf injection. This and last week's EIA print corroborate strong weather-aided demand. Our preliminary storage injection estimate for the week ending August 22 is 51 Bcf. Beyond the forecast injection for the week in progress, decidedly more shoulder season injections are on the horizon as cooling load dissipates both seasonally and on current weather forecasts

- TODAY - JPM European Oil & Gas "Back to School" Fireside Series, Aug 29th-Sept 8th, Virtual.Join our bi-annual European Oil & Gas "Back to School" Series, an event designed to provide a consolidated end-of-summer platform to take stock on key issues / catalysts into year-end, both sector and corporate. Corporates confirmed so far include SPM, ENI, EQNR, NESTE, TTE, VAR, OMV, GALP and SHEL and we expect to add further participants over the coming weeks. The format will be 45 minutes of fireside discussions moderated by J.P. Morgan research analysts; Let me know if you want the links to register.

- REGISTRATION OPEN - JP Morgan Global Energy Conference, Nov 3-4th, London, in-person. J.P. Morgan Global Energy Conference will take place in-person on Nov 3rd and 4th at J.P. Morgan's 60 Victoria Embankment offices, London EC4Y 0JP. This year's agenda will address a range of macro, thematic and policy topics which we expect to be on the energy sector's critical path during 2026, sessions include Jean-Pierre Sbraire, CFO, TotalEnergies; Kadri Simson, Former European Commissioner for Energy; Francesco Gattei, CFO, ENI, an expert panel on the implications of AI for Energy/Power and a

keynote discussion with Jamie Dimon, Chairman and CEO of JPM. Over 35 corporates confirmed across Oil&Gas, OFS, E&P, Utilities and Renewables - let me know if you full details/Agenda and/or to sign- up.
Oil Macro and Flows  Company News  Macro News  Global Oil & Gas Research  J.P. Morgan Global Oil & Gas Access  Sector Calendar  J.P. Morgan Global Oil & Gas Contacts

- Leavitt commented that Trump was unhappy about Russia's attacks on Ukraine hinted at further announcements, sparking fears in the market of further sanctions that may be used to push an end to the war.  
- German chancellor Merz said a meeting between Putin and Zelensky apparently won't happen  
- Russian President Putin will meet with Indian leader Modi and Chinese leader Xi Jinping at the Shanghai Cooperation Organization summit to discuss energy partnerships. Putin's agenda includes ensuring India maintains a healthy level of Russian crude imports despite US pressure, and getting China to unblock a gas pipeline to help Moscow replace sales to Europe.  
- Saudi Aramco may reduce the official selling price of Arab Light crude by 50c/bbl for sales to Asia in October, according to the median estimate in a Bloomberg survey of seven traders and refiners. Four respondents estimated a decline of 45c-50c/bbl m/m, one saw a 70c drop, while the two expected a decline of \$1  
- The Arctic Mulan vessel, which was carrying a shipment from the US-sanctioned Arctic LNG 2 export plant in Russia, has started moving away after docking at a Chinese terminal on Thursday, according to ship-tracking data compiled by Bloomberg. Unclear if cargo was discharged; ship data shows draft unchanged, which means it may not have discharged

- Crude was relatively choppy throughout the day, but ultimately spiked in the afternoon following Leavitt's comments. In addition, German chancellor Merz said a meeting between Putin and Zelensky apparently won't happen, which is very different sentiment from a couple weeks ago when he was discussing security guarantees for Ukraine in hopes of a deal. Without an announcement from Trump, prices may revert after today's spike, however in the coming weeks another sanctions package is expected from European countries, posing further bullish risk.

- The backdrop of oversupply in 4q suggests that if the sanctions packages are not significantly restrictive and Trump and other leaders shift focus away from brokering a deal, we may start to see prices retrace.

Markets - SPX was up 30bps from the European close to finish 0.32% higher on the day (6,502). It was a risk-on session with cyclicals outperforming defenses by almost 2%. Momentum L/S 12m recovered yesterday loss finishing up 1.94% with TMT Crowded Longs up more than 2.50%. Overall volumes tracked 14% below the 30 dma as treasury yields and USD sold off with Oil moving higher. Communication services and energy were the best sectors with utilities and staples the worst. JPM cash was slightly better to buy with financials and healthcare leading the skew. Tech and consumer discretionary were better for sale. After the close Dell - 5%. The press is looking at this weekend energy summit in China between Putin, Xi and Modi and France political situation. Overnight USD and treasuries have remained mainly flat and commodities are lower. Today in US we have PCE, Consumer Spending and UMich Consumer Sentiment. In Europe we have ECB CPI Expectations and Germany, France, Italy and Spain CPI. Asia markets are higher with the exception of Japan and Korea. JPM cash volumes are +10% vs 5dma and we are 1.5x better to buy. We are buying in China, Japan, Korea and Indonesia vs selling in Australia, HK, Taiwan and Singapore. In the sectors we are buying industrials, consumer discretionary and materials versus selling tech and financials. MOVES VS YESTERDAY'S EUROPEAN CLOSE; S&P minis +23bps, Nasdaq minis +11bps, Nikkei fut - 61bps, FTSE futs +10bps, Eurostoxx futs - 6bps; US Momentum - 19bps, US Value +65bps; DXY +5bps, EUR - 7bps, GBP - 12bps, CHF - 6bps, CNH - 4bps, JPY +4bps, Bitcoin - 1%; US 2y rates unch @ 3.63%, US 10y rates unch @ 4.21%, Germany 10y rates unch @ 2.7%, UK 10y rates unch @ 4.7%; Copper +54bps, Gold +8bps, Brent +1%, WTI +1%, Steel Rebar futs - 54bps, Iron ore futs - 6bps
Flows - HF buyer Shell, LO Seller OMV, HF Seller EQNR

- BP's refinery in Whiting, Indiana, is showing increased activity at two of the last three units still shut since an Aug. 19 rainstorm forced multiple units offline, according to a report from Wood Mackenzie Thursday. 
- The 70k b/d CDU Pipestill 11A crude unit and a 56k b/d diesel hydrotreater began showing increased activity, including heating, during Thursday morning. The two units remain offline, along with a 24k b/d hydrotreater 
- Units already restarted include the 115k b/d Pipestill 11-C CDU, two 60k b/d vacuum distillation units, a 115k b/d FCC, 80k b/d FCC, 100k b/d cat feed hydrotreater and 85k b/d naphtha hydrotreater

Oil Markets Weekly: Tariffs on India kick in—Russian oil flows likely to continue at limited discounts (research available) Despite higher tariffs, India continues to buy Russian crude at reduced levels, a trend likely to persist until a trade deal is finalized and Russia maintains discounts

Russia has successfully redirected the 0.5 mbd drop in Indian exports but is unlikely to offer discounts beyond the current \(\) 2.60\$ / bbl, preferring to cut production over providing the deep discounts seen in 2022
Since 2021, India's crude imports and refinery runs have grown significantly, while exports have remained flat due to rising domestic demand

However, of the 1.8 mbd of Russian crude imported by India, nearly 1 mbs is refined and exported, mainly by private operators With only 0.2 mbd of this being shipped to the EU, India should face no issues in complying with EU third- country intermediaries restrictions
India operates within global policy frameworks, with Russia bearing the responsibility for delivery Click here

- Today's EIA print once more came in below market expectations, which called for a build in the high 20s Bcf but was relatively in line with our supply-demand forecast calling for a 21 Bcf injection. Our lower-than-consensus estimate was driven by power burns that were trending above 49 Bcf/day for the reference week, according to EIA 930 data (Figure 1). We believe today's and last week's EIA print corroborate strong weather-aided demand with estimated gas power burn above 49 Bcf/day for the reference week and the week ending August 15. Based on forecasts as of this morning, August gas power burn looks on track to average just above 46 Bcf/d, which still represents a \(\sim 2\) Bcf/day year-over-year decline.

- Our preliminary storage injection estimate for the week ending August 22 is 51 Bcf. Daily gas power burn appears to be on track to fall nearly 5 Bcf/day week-over-week, and this decline is the main driver of that substantially higher injection rate (Figure 1). We also note that EIA 930 data point to lower week-over-week coal-fired power generation more in line with levels last seen in May and June (Figure 2). Pipeline data suggest that production is up week-over-week, and we have built in a 0.6 Bcf/day week-over-week increase versus the reference week. The Pacific region storage sample is showing a higher week-over-week withdrawal compared to the reference week. EIA 930 data for CAISO through yesterday show a 1 Bcf/day increase week-over-week in power burn for the region. Beyond the forecast injection for the week in progress, decidedly more shoulder season injections are on the horizon as cooling load dissipates both seasonally and on current weather forecasts
Tariffs on India kick in—Russian oil flows likely to continue at limited discounts (Natasha Kaneva)
Despite higher tariffs, India continues to buy Russian crude at reduced levels, a trend likely to persist until a trade deal is finalized and Russia maintains discounts

Weekly data for California (week ended 8/22) were recently reported. Total clean products drew by \(\sim 424\) kbbls w/w, \(\sim 17\) kbbls above the 2020- 24 average. On specifics for this week's data, gasoline inventories drew by \(\sim 366\) kbbls (putting inventories \(\sim 476\) kbbls above the 2020- 24 seasonal average), and gasoline production fell by \(\sim 31\) kbpd to \(\sim 871\) kbpd ( \(\sim 65\) kbpd below the 2020- 24 average). Diesel inventories drew by \(\sim 58\) kbbls ( \(\sim 459\) kbbls below the 2020- 24 seasonal average) and diesel production fell by \(\sim 43\) kbpd to \(\sim 208\) kbpd ( \(\sim 56\) kbpd below the 2020- 24 seasonal average). Crude input was down \(\sim 59\) kbw w/at \(\sim 1.363\) mmbpd (in the bottom half of the seasonal range, \(\sim 40\) kbpd below the 2020- 24 average). Crude inventories increased by \(\sim 13\) kbbls to \(\sim 11.770\) mmbbls, below seasonal lows. On crack spreads, LA gasoline cracks were up w/w, in the middle of the seasonal range, while diesel cracks were flattish w/w, also in the middle of the seasonal range.

Decent 2Q25 results. Aethon's 2Q25 results were roughly in line with our expectations, and the company reaffirmed its FY25 production and capex guidance. We look for further outlook and activity commentary during the call. As expected, there were no comments on press reports on expected M&A.

At the margin, the account of the ECB's July meeting sounded slightly more open- minded about the possibility of a further rate cut than the impression Lagarde gave at the press conference. However, combined with comments and "sources" articles since then, the impression remains that the ECB will be on hold in September and that it needs a push to ease after that. We continue to expect one more cut (in October), but this requires some combination of downside risks to growth and/or a refocusing by the ECB on an inflation forecast that is already running below target despite having further easing factored in. That puts the focus on the next round of PMI surveys and upcoming inflation reports, starting with tomorrow's national releases for August, which we think will show soft core inflation momentum.
